name: 1579_B. Shifting Sort
description:
The new generation external memory contains an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment. 
  2. Then you replace the segment a[l … r] with it's cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2. 



For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]
prompt:
The new generation external memory consists of an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment. You have the freedom to choose any pair of indices for l and r within this constraint. This selection will define the segment you can work with.
  2. Then you replace the segment a[l … r] with it's cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2. 

For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]

completions:
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def cyclic_shift_sort(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing an integer k and a list of tuples representing the actions (l, r, d).
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n - 1):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = r - l
                segment = array[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment
                actions.append((l, r, d))
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Call the function
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(*action)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and a list of shift details.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # A simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n - 1):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the minimum element to the correct position
                d = min_index - i
                actions.append((i + 1, min_index + 1, d))
                array[i:min_index + 1] = array[i + d:min_index + 1] + array[i:i + d]

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

if __name__ == "__main__":
    # Input interface
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Output interface
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(*action)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def cyclic_shift_sort(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of actions and a list of actions (l, r, d).
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n - 1):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = r - l
                actions.append((l, r, d))
                
                # Perform the cyclic shift on the array
                segment = array[l-1:r]
                array[l-1:r] = segment[d:] + segment[:d]

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

if __name__ == "__main__":
    # Input interface
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Call the function and get the result
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(action[0], action[1], action[2])
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts and returns the number of shifts and their descriptions.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]): List of test cases, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]: List of results for each test case, where each result contains the number of shifts and the shift actions.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_a = sorted(a)

        if a == sorted_a:
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n):
            if a[i] != sorted_a[i]:
                # Find the correct position of the current element
                correct_pos = sorted_a.index(a[i])
                if correct_pos > i:
                    # Perform a cyclic shift
                    segment_length = correct_pos - i + 1
                    offset = segment_length - 1
                    actions.append((i + 1, correct_pos + 1, offset))
                    # Perform the cyclic shift
                    a[i:correct_pos + 1] = a[i + offset:correct_pos + 1] + a[i:i + offset]

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(' '.join(map(str, action)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts each test case array using cyclic shifts and returns the operations performed.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing an integer k (number of operations) and a list of operations.
        Each operation is a tuple (l, r, d) representing the cyclic shift parameters.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        if a == sorted(a):
            # If the array is already sorted, no operations are needed.
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        operations = []
        # A simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n - 1):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if a[j] < a[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the minimum element to the correct position
                # Shift the segment a[i...min_index] to the left by 1
                operations.append((i + 1, min_index + 1, 1))
                a[i:min_index + 1] = a[i + 1:min_index + 1] + [a[i]]

        results.append((len(operations), operations))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sort arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of operations and a list of operations.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)

        if array == sorted_array:
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n):
            if array[i:] != sorted_array[i:]:
                # Find the segment to shift
                l = i + 1
                r = n
                d = 1

                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = array[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment

                # Record the action
                actions.append((l, r, d))

                # Check if sorted
                if array == sorted_array:
                    break

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

def main():
    """Main function to read input and output results."""
    # Read number of test cases
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []

    # Read each test case
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Get results from the sorting function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output results
    for k, actions in results:
        print(k)
        for l, r, d in actions:
            print(l, r, d)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Returns:

    for n, array in test_cases:

                # Perform the cyclic shift

                array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment
                actions.append((l, r, d))

from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def cyclic_shift_sort(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts and returns the number of shifts and their details.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]): List of test cases, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]: For each test case, returns the number of shifts and the details of each shift.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = r - l
                array[i:r] = array[i+1:r] + [array[i]]
                actions.append((l, r, d))
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Output interface
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:

    for n, a in test_cases:
        if a == sorted(a):
            results.append((0, []))
            continue
        
        actions = []
        sorted_a = sorted(a)
        
        # We will perform at most n operations
        for i in range(n):
            if a == sorted_a:
                break
            
            # Find the first element that is out of place
            for j in range(n - 1):
                if a[j] > a[j + 1]:
                    # Perform a cyclic shift to correct the order
                    l = j + 1
                    r = n
                    d = 1
                    segment = a[l-1:r]
                    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                    a[l-1:r] = shifted_segment
                    actions.append((l, r, d))

# Input interface

from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def cyclic_shift_sort(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing an integer k and a list of tuples representing the operations.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        operations = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)

        if array == sorted_array:
            results.append((0, operations))
            continue

        # We will perform a simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n):
            if array == sorted_array:
                break

            # Find the first element that is not in the correct position
            for j in range(n - 1):
                if array[j] > array[j + 1]:
                    # Perform a cyclic shift on the segment [j, j+1]
                    l = j + 1
                    r = j + 2
                    d = 1
                    segment = array[l-1:r]
                    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                    array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment
                    operations.append((l, r, d))
                    break

        results.append((len(operations), operations))

    return results

if __name__ == "__main__":
    # Input interface
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Call the function and get the result
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(action[0], action[1], action[2])

requirement analysis:

Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating elements within a specified segment of an array to the left by a given offset. This operation allows rearranging elements without changing their relative order outside the segment.

    'segment'
    Explanation: A segment is a contiguous subarray defined by two indices, l and r, within the array. The cyclic shift is applied only to this segment.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n'
    Explanation: The requirement specifies that the number of cyclic shifts used to sort the array should not exceed the length of the array, n. This means we can perform up to n shifts to achieve sorting.

# [degree adverb]
    No degree adverb

# [code logic]
    1. For each test case, read the integer n and the array a.
    2. Check if the array is already sorted. If so, output k = 0.
    3. If not sorted, identify segments that can be cyclically shifted to move elements into their correct positions.
    4. Use list slicing to perform cyclic shifts on identified segments.
    5. Keep track of the number of shifts and their details (l, r, d).
    6. Ensure the number of shifts does not exceed n.
    7. Output the number of shifts and their details for each test case.

# [edge case]
    Input: [1, 1, 1, 1] = 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted as all elements are identical, so no shifts are needed.

    Input: [10, -10] = 1
    Explanation: The array is not sorted, but only one shift is needed to sort it: shift the segment [10, -10] by offset 1.

    Input: [5, 4, 3, 2, 1] = 4
    Explanation: The array is in reverse order, requiring multiple shifts to sort it. Each shift can move one element into its correct position.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The original logic of checking if the array is already sorted and performing shifts as needed will handle these cases effectively.

# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating a segment of the array to the left by a specified offset. This means that elements in the segment are moved to the left, and elements that fall off the left end are wrapped around to the right end of the segment.

    'sort using cyclic shifts'
    Explanation: The task is to sort the array by performing a series of cyclic shifts. The number of shifts should not exceed the length of the array, n.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n cyclic shifts': The number of cyclic shifts performed should be less than or equal to n, where n is the length of the array.
    Implementation: Ensure that the count of cyclic shifts does not exceed n.

# [degree adverb]
    'arbitrary': This indicates that any valid indices and offset can be chosen for the cyclic shift as long as they meet the constraints.
    Implementation: Use any valid l, r, and d values that help achieve sorting.

# [code logic]
1. For each test case, read the length of the array and the array itself.
2. Check if the array is already sorted. If it is, output k = 0.
3. If not sorted, perform cyclic shifts:
   - Identify segments that can be shifted to move elements closer to their sorted positions.
   - Use list slicing to perform cyclic shifts on identified segments.
   - Keep track of each shift operation (l, r, d) and ensure the number of operations does not exceed n.
4. Output the number of operations and their details for each test case.

# [edge case]
    Case 1: Input: [1, 2] = 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted, so no shifts are needed.

    Case 2: Input: [2, 1] = 1
    Explanation: A single shift of segment [1, 2] with d = 1 will sort the array.

    Case 3: Input: [3, 3, 3] = 0
    Explanation: All elements are identical, so the array is already sorted.

We will implement a function that sorts arrays using cyclic shifts. The approach will involve identifying segments of the array that can be cyclically shifted to move elements into their correct positions. We will use a simple algorithm that iteratively selects segments and applies cyclic shifts until the array is sorted. The solution will handle multiple test cases efficiently and ensure the number of operations does not exceed the length of the array. We will use Python's built-in list operations to perform cyclic shifts.
Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating a segment of the array to the left by a specified offset, effectively moving elements within the segment while maintaining their order.

    'sort using cyclic shifts'
    Explanation: The task is to sort the array by performing a series of cyclic shifts on segments of the array, ensuring that the number of shifts does not exceed the length of the array.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n'
    Explanation: The number of cyclic shifts performed should not exceed the length of the array, n. This means that for an array of length n, you can perform up to n cyclic shifts to sort it.

# [degree adverb]
    No degree adverb

# [code logic]
1. For each test case, read the integer n and the array a.
2. Check if the array is already sorted. If it is, output k = 0 and move to the next test case.
3. If not sorted, identify segments that can be cyclically shifted to move elements closer to their correct positions.
4. For each identified segment, perform a cyclic shift and record the operation (l, r, d).
5. Repeat the process until the array is sorted or until n operations have been performed.
6. Output the number of operations k and the list of operations for each test case.

# [edge case]
    Test case 1: [1, 1] = 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted, so no operations are needed.

    Test case 2: [3, 3, 3] = 0
    Explanation: All elements are identical, so the array is already sorted.

    Test case 3: [5, 4, 3, 2, 1] = 5
    Explanation: The array is in reverse order, requiring multiple shifts to sort.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The original logic of checking if the array is already sorted and performing up to n operations will naturally handle these cases.
examples:
Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]
